user_request: A Mother's Day poem about how a mother's love is unconditional.

revision_history.draft:
The clock’s pulse is a metronome  
she never winds, yet it keeps  
time in the kitchen’s slow breath.  
You brush your teeth with the rhythm  
of a vacuum’s hum—  
a frequency you’ve never named,  
only felt, like the roots  
of the plant in the corner,  
spreading silent,  
unseen.  

Her hands, a map of threads  
weaving the blanket you’ll outgrow  
before you know its shape.  
You sleep in the folds,  
unaware the mattress  
is stitched with her sighs,  
the pillowstuff  
a quiet rebellion  
against the weight of your head.  

The dishes, always clean,  
stacked in a tower of silence—  
she’s the gravity you don’t notice,  
the force that holds your world  
together,  
a gravity you’ll never measure.  
You grow,  
unquestioning,  
while the walls  
absorb the echo of her voice,  
a sound you’ve never learned to name.

The clock’s pulse is a metronome  
she never winds, yet it keeps  
time in the kitchen’s slow breath.  
You brush your teeth with the rhythm  
of a vacuum’s hum—  
a frequency you’ve never named,  
only felt, like the roots  
of the plant in the corner,  
spreading silent,  
unseen.  

Her hands, a map of threads  
weaving the blanket you’ll outgrow  
before you know its shape.  
You sleep in the folds,  
unaware the mattress  
is stitched with her sighs,  
the pillowstuff  
a quiet rebellion  
against the weight of your head.  

The dishes, always clean,  
stacked in a tower of silence—  
she’s the gravity you don’t notice,  
the force that holds your world  
together,  
a gravity you’ll never measure.  
You grow,  
unquestioning,  
while the walls  
absorb the echo of her voice,  
a sound you’ve never learned to name.

The clock’s pulse is a metronome

only felt, like the roots  
of the plant in the corner,

unseen.  

Her hands, a map of threads

before you know its shape.  
You sleep in the folds,  
unaware the mattress

the pillowstuff  
a quiet rebellion

The dishes, always clean,
